metadata.name: CEI Benchmark
metadata.description: Contextual Emotional Inference benchmark for pragmatic reasoning

scenarios.context: A 16-year-old daughter comes home late and quietly knocks on her mother's bedroom door, saying they were scared when she didn't answer her phone. The teen asks, "Are you mad at me?"
scenarios.utterance: It's a school night you know, did you get all your homework done?

scenarios.context: A 28-year-old daughter is on the phone with their mother; the mother asks how the daughter is handling her recent divorce and whether she needs help. The daughter has been struggling but doesn't want to worry the parent.
scenarios.utterance: I'm starting a new project at work, it's really interesting.

scenarios.context: A discussion between a salesperson and their field engineer after the engineer skipped a scheduled client call. The salesperson directly asks the field engineering about why they missed the call.
scenarios.utterance: I wouldn't say 'skipped' so much as 'jumped' - know what I mean?

scenarios.context: A father is texting his 19-year-old son, who just called him out for missing not pickuping the son up after practice. The son asks why he didn't show up.
scenarios.utterance: Don't worry, I'm on my way now.

scenarios.context: A group chat of friends on Messenger where one man recently hinted they were upset after a breakup; a friend asks if they're okay.
scenarios.utterance: OK? I'm about as sound as the English pound.

scenarios.context: A group chat of friends where one member just asked the group coordinator if they're okay after hinting they're going through a rough breakup.
scenarios.utterance: Wait, I think I forgot the veggie tray in my car.

scenarios.context: A man recently broke up with their partner. A close friend texts asking if he's actually okay, since they've been distant. Both are peers who used to date.
scenarios.utterance: Just as OK as I was after we broke up.

scenarios.context: A man texts a partner he is dating to ask why they didn't respond after a tense thread message the previous night. The partner replies quickly with an upbeat plan.
scenarios.utterance: Oh my god, why so serious. We should plan a beach day next weekend: sunscreen, snacks, and a ridiculous playlist. You in?

scenarios.context: A professor asks why their colleague skipped an important event they were expected to attend together.
scenarios.utterance: I wouldn't say 'skipped' so much as 'jumped' - know what I mean?

scenarios.context: A younger friend asks the more experienced friend if they regret ghosting someone they once dated who later became the popular girl in high school.
scenarios.utterance: I was the one who made her popular

scenarios.context: A younger spouse asks an older spouse whether they can talk about estate planning.
scenarios.utterance: What, are you pushing me into an early grave now?

scenarios.context: After a manager raises specific concerns, deliverables, and deadlines in a feedback meeting about several missed follow-ups, a marketing associate responds.
scenarios.utterance: Oh wow, thanks for the heads-up. I'll get right on that.

scenarios.context: After a professor texts a reminder that the intern missed sending slides for a lab meeting, the research intern replies with an upbeat logistics-focused message instead of apologizing or explaining the delay.
scenarios.utterance: If the data is ready and the analytics model works we should have visualizations ready soon

scenarios.context: After a tense conversation where a woman raises concerns about their partner's emotional availability, the woman pushes for a serious discussion about priorities. The partner responds quickly.
scenarios.utterance: Available? 24/7 baby

scenarios.context: After a tense exchange about who borrowed Dad's car without asking, the father hold up his son's distinctive jacket left in car this morning.
scenarios.utterance: You got a jacket just like mine!

scenarios.context: After a tense text exchange where the older sister asked the younger brother whether he has been showing up for his prison release job shifts, the younger brother replies in the family group chat.
scenarios.utterance: Don't worry. It's hard work but I can handle it.

scenarios.context: After coming home late, a teenager's parent confronts them about breaking curfew and asks where they were.
scenarios.utterance: I feel asleep in the library and sped read in my sleep.

scenarios.context: After the acocunt manager lost the firms largest client, the partners demand an explanation of what happened.
scenarios.utterance: The client felt the long-term synergy between our firm and their future vision was misaligned along multiple dimensions.

scenarios.context: After their first date the younger partner texts that they felt hurt the older man didn't call the next day; the older partner (more socially experienced) replies in a bright, planning tone.
scenarios.utterance: I'm so terrible with my phone lately, but you know what they say "bigger plans take more time."

scenarios.context: An adult son calls, upset about not getting an expected scholarship and worried his father won't pay his full college tuition without it. His father hears the news and responds.
scenarios.utterance: I'm really sorry to hear that buddy. Well,  things usually turn out of the best.

scenarios.context: At a cafe, a younger friend asks their older friend if the younger friend is still seeing the person they'd been dating a few months ago, after rumors at a mutual friend's party.
scenarios.utterance: Still seeing them? Like you're seeing your partner? BTW, hows that going?

scenarios.context: At a cramped family kitchen after a tense phone call about their mother's upcoming surgery, two adult siblings are sitting across from each other. The sister sibling asks her brother sibling if he's handling the news okay.
scenarios.utterance: Your right, this has got to be hard on mom.

scenarios.context: At a family group chat, the youngest son who borrowed money from their parents hasn't paid it back. An older sister asks a direct question about whether the son paid Mom back after several reminders.
scenarios.utterance: Oh yeah, mom really helped me out with those old medical bills.

scenarios.context: At a quiet family dinner, your younger sibling asks if you told Mom and Dad about losing your job earlier this month.
scenarios.utterance: Oh wowâ remember when Dad burned the Thanksgiving turkey and we all pretended it was 'extra crispy'?

scenarios.context: At a small dinner, a Bob asks an Alice who just split up with Jim whether they're okay and if Alice wants to talk about what happened.
scenarios.utterance: Speaking of which, remember when we went tricker-treating together in 3rd grade.

scenarios.context: At a weekend breakfast, an adult daughter asks her father whether he'll bring up last week's argument at the family dinner. The daughter expects a direct answer about whether he'll apologize.
scenarios.utterance: It's not much of an "argument" if I'm right now is it?

scenarios.context: At an all-hands an employee asks the CEO directly whether the circulating layoff rumors are true. The question hangs in the room.
scenarios.utterance: I can't verfiy any rumours circulating about, but we've got pizza in the kitchen if anyone's hungry!

scenarios.context: At the kitchen table the teenager asks her mother directly if the parents are separating after noticing boxes in the garage and seeing her father staying elsewhere overnight.
scenarios.utterance: Oh, aren't we the nosey nellies?

scenarios.context: Direct message to your book editor after they asked an author for a timeline update on the next chapter and for a plan to have a draft by next week.
scenarios.utterance: I'm working on it night and day and will get back to you next week.

scenarios.context: During a check-in the employee directly asks whether there's budget for a promotion this quarter; the manager responds quickly.
scenarios.utterance: That's a great questionâI'll have HR send you the details.

scenarios.context: During a mid-year compensation discussion after a great performance review, the employee asks their manager whether a promised raise will be applied this quarter.
scenarios.utterance: Yes, raises can be contingent upon performance reviews.

scenarios.context: During a mid-year review, the team lead brings up repeated late arrivals and asks a specific employee whether there are ongoing issues affecting their punctuality.
scenarios.utterance: I bet I get to the office before you tomorrow.

scenarios.context: During a one-on-one peer check-in, Alex asks Jamie why the construction project missed the deadline after Jamie had promised it would be met.
scenarios.utterance: Let's put a pin in that for now and move on to new topics.

scenarios.context: During a party, a guy pauses as the topic turns to why they looked upset earlier. His roomate asked if he's still upset his best friend is now dating his immediate ex-partner.
scenarios.utterance: I think they'll make a great couple. They deserve each other.

scenarios.context: During a quiet family dinner, the mother asks her adult son why he hasn't transferred his share of the rent this month after several reminders.
scenarios.utterance: Oh yeah, let me get right on that.

scenarios.context: During a vulnerable moment the man asks his partner directly whether they have feelings for them. The partner appears less certain and nervous.
scenarios.utterance: Sure, I have feelings for everyone.

scenarios.context: During a weekend visit, a mother asks her adult son why he still hasn't transferred his share of the rent after several reminders.
scenarios.utterance: Yeah, about that Mom, thank a load to help me out with a place to crash after my last eviction.

scenarios.context: Email from a student to a professor asking for an explanation of a low grade and whether a resubmission would be allowed.
scenarios.utterance: You can see the grade breakdown on the syllabus

scenarios.context: In a company Slack DM, an engineering manager follows up after a missed feature deadline; the junior engineer asked whether the delay will affect their performance review.
scenarios.utterance: Oh wow, that deadline stuff is annoyingâ€”remember when we finished the Q1 rollout in two sleepless days? Also, have you tried the new coffee machine in the break room yet?

scenarios.context: In a family group message, a father asks his adult daughter if they will still come to the big weekend game after an earlier family fight at Thanksgiving.
scenarios.utterance: Oh, I forgot about the game. BTW, remember when I tripped at the championship soccer match and you still cheered me on?

scenarios.context: In a group chat among friends after one member asked if someone was okay after the fatal car accident they walked away from.
scenarios.utterance: The crazy thing was that the other driver didn't have any insurance.

scenarios.context: In a living room, a girlfriend asks another student if they're okay after seeing a detailed and highly specific breakup text up on the students phone. They're close and often candid, but this is a sensitive moment.
scenarios.utterance: Maybe it was delivered to the wrong phone number?

scenarios.context: In a meeting among co-workers, the packaging engineer calls out the designer for not replying to an urgent request last weekend.
scenarios.utterance: I always promptly respond to urgent requests. So your message last week must not have been that urgent

scenarios.context: In a private Slack 1:1, a manager asks a junior developer why they missed the deadline on a deliverable and whether there were technical obstacles the manager should know about.
scenarios.utterance: If I only had more time I think we'd hit the milestones.

scenarios.context: In a private Slack DM, the product_director asks the marketing_intern whether the launch checklist and metrics are ready; the intern replies immediately with an upbeat, unrelated suggestion.
scenarios.utterance: Alsoâ€”have you tried the new cafÃ© on 3rd? Their croissants are unreal; we should grab coffee after the launch!

scenarios.context: In a private bar a junior salesperson asks their manager directly whether the rumored round of layoffs will affect their team after a terse all-hands meeting is called. Thee manager replies immediately.
scenarios.utterance: Not as long as we don't forget to bring all our hands to the meeting tomorrow.

scenarios.context: In a project Slack channel a senior developer points out that a colleague's missing commit caused a small delay and asks what the plan is to fix it.
scenarios.utterance: No worries at all! If we get the backend working then the front end should be fine.

scenarios.context: In a small-team discussion a customer support manager brings up a well-known bugs in the company software and gently asks the engineer manager when the bugs will be fixed.
scenarios.utterance: Are you sure it's not user errors?

scenarios.context: In the office kitchen, one colleague brings up that Jamie's slides skipped several key data points and asks if Jamie can explain.
scenarios.utterance: No worries, I've brought donuts for everyone, let's all grab one! Also, who's up for moving the Friday coffee run to earlier?

scenarios.context: In the school cafeteria, the classmate asks whether the college student told their latest date they didn't want exclusivity. The speaker replies while grinning.
scenarios.utterance: I'm as exculsive as I'm allowed to be.

scenarios.context: On a quick phone call, an older sibling asks the younger sibling if they forgot to pick up their grandmother from the train station.
scenarios.utterance: I thought you were going to pick gram-gram up?

scenarios.context: On a second date a woman asks her date, 'Where do you see this going?' after a serious comment about exclusivity.
scenarios.utterance: Right now I see us going to dinner and a movie.

scenarios.context: On a second date, the conversation turns serious when the woman asks her partner whether they should be exclusive.
scenarios.utterance: You bet, as serious as a heart attack!

scenarios.context: On a walk, a younger ex asks their older ex whether they'd ever consider getting back together; the conversation feels tense and the question is direct.
scenarios.utterance: Did we ever really break up?

scenarios.context: On the company shipping status webpage, Taylor is asked by the shipping manager about why they didn't post the update that was due an hour ago and what's being done about it now.
scenarios.utterance: Oh no, my bad! Totally spaced out.

scenarios.context: Slack DM between two teammates after a missed deadline. The project lead asks the database manager for an explanation about why a deliverable wasn't updated before the review.
scenarios.utterance: Why do they call it a "deadline" anyway. We're both still alive and kicking aren't we?

scenarios.context: That's a pretty personal question to ask on only the third date.
scenarios.utterance: Haha, no, but there's this new taco truckâ€”want to grab dinner Friday?

scenarios.context: Walking home together after an awkward conversation where Pat asked whether Alister had been seeing someone else, Person Alister responds immediately with a cheerful plan.
scenarios.utterance: Yeah, I see other people all the time, every day, all over the placeÉ in class, on TV, on the sidewalksÉ

scenarios.context: While everyone waits for dessert at a family gathering, a cousin asks how you're holding up since your recent breakup.
scenarios.utterance: Not was well as the souffle we had, yum!

scenarios.context: You're in a quiet conversation with your parnter after they asked you point-blank whether you see the relationship going somewhere; the question felt tense and direct.
scenarios.utterance: To the moon baby! To the moon.

scenarios.context: A 23-year-old adult child texts their parent at 2:15 AM after a rough day at work. The parent often responds quickly when worried but has also been short tempered lately, claiming to be exhausted from extra shifts.
scenarios.utterance: You're doing fine, just call me if you need anything.

scenarios.context: A colleague stayed late to fix a bug and pushed a rushed patch. The next morning an angry customer leave feedback on the user support website.
scenarios.utterance: This fix could've been much better; next time, don't rush it.

scenarios.context: A father has been staying up late to help his daughter with college applications and responds after she procrastinated again.
scenarios.utterance: How do you want me to help if you won't take this seriously.

scenarios.context: A father stayed late helping his adult child rehearse an important job presentation. Afterward, the adult child did okay but not as well as hoped.
scenarios.utterance: I tried to help you last night. Maybe you just practiced too much.

scenarios.context: A father who is usually protective and has defended her to others, has been staying late to help his unemployed adult daughter with applications and responds after finding dirty laundry piling up in the living room
scenarios.utterance: This is seriously the last time I'm cleaning up after you.

scenarios.context: A friend you've been seeing casually texts you late, asking if you still want to keep seeing them romantically. You had been slow to reply all week and missed a call earlier.
scenarios.utterance: Lol, seriously?

scenarios.context: A manager messages a junior analyst in a team Slack channel about a client report. The manager has previously defended the junior in meetings and has provided one-on-one coaching, but the deadline pressures are high and the report contains clear errors.
scenarios.utterance: You can do better than this. But if you can't, let me know.

scenarios.context: A mentor, who often defends and helps you, responded after a late-night review of your work.
scenarios.utterance: That was sloppy. Please fix before our next meeting, and keep up the good work.

scenarios.context: A mother has been staying up late to help her 13-year-old with repeated school assignments. After cleaning up the child's messy desk again the mother snaps.
scenarios.utterance: This is the absolute last time I'm cleaning up after you. Alright?

scenarios.context: A mother texts her 17-year-old son at 11:45 PM after hearing his teacher called about a failing grade; she has been handling late-night school crises for him for months and is visibly tired.
scenarios.utterance: You'll be fine, don't worry, relax, just try harder next time.

scenarios.context: A mother texts her college-age son after he missed a couple of scheduled health center check-ins and turned in a late assignment.
scenarios.utterance: I know you can do it, so please don't make a habit of this.

scenarios.context: A mother who has been distant lately replies to her younger child's excited message about a school recital. She has missed recent events but always promises she'll make the next one.
scenarios.utterance: I'll be there if I can.

scenarios.context: A senior engineer posts a terse code-review comment late at night on a junior developer's pull request fix. That senior has previously stayed late to help this developer but the current message is short and abrupt.
scenarios.utterance: This is sloppy; need to fix it before I push it live.

scenarios.context: A tired father calls his 16-year-old daughter late at night after a long day at work. She's been anxious about college applications and he missed filing a key form required for her application.
scenarios.utterance: Don't worry, I've taken care of it already. It'll be done by tomorrow.

scenarios.context: A younger brother stayed up late to help his older sister edit her grad-school application. After sending his notes, he texts a very blunt line of feedback.
scenarios.utterance: Honestly, if that's the best you can do maybe it's good enough.

scenarios.context: After a code review in a small engineering team, a senior teammate who has repeatedly defended the junior developer in previous meetings posts feedback on the recent commit.
scenarios.utterance: Nice work, but you'll need to redo most of it.

scenarios.context: After a fight, your cousin has been distant for weeks and hasn't visited. They send a short message offering you a way back in.
scenarios.utterance: If you ever want to come by, the door may be open.

scenarios.context: After a mildly awkward first date, one friend texts the other the next morning. The texting friend had been the one to suggest meeting but the date ended early and the other friend hasn't reached out since.
scenarios.utterance: We’re cool, right?

scenarios.context: After a month of sporadic texts and less contact, an older ex who usually initiates plans sends a brief message to you offering to meet up.
scenarios.utterance: If you want to catch up, let me know.

scenarios.context: After a successful quarter, the manager sends a quick update to employees whose responsibilities are being shifted in an upcoming reorganization.
scenarios.utterance: Look at our revenue from last quarter, this upcoming reorg will make us even more efficient.

scenarios.context: After a tense develoepr sprint demo where a bug was pointed out, you get a short direct message from a teammate who stayed late this week to help you with the feature.
scenarios.utterance: You're code clobbered by recent updates, but don't worry about it.

scenarios.context: After a tense project meeting where the manager pointed out multiple issues, you (an employee) stayed late to rework the slides and sent a short reply the next morning addressing their concerns.
scenarios.utterance: You're doing fine, just don't make so many mistakes next time.

scenarios.context: After an apparently great date, a woman follows up with a compliment but notes their overcommitted schedule.
scenarios.utterance: Can't wait to see you again, but we're going to have to wait until things clear up on my calendar.

scenarios.context: After an awkward client call, the manager texts the junior analyst from home late at night.
scenarios.utterance: We lost the client. Don't worry, get  some rest, and we'll go over it tomorrow.

scenarios.context: After repeatedly missing small but important details, the manager who has been staying late to help confronts the associate in a one-on-one meeting.
scenarios.utterance: That was sloppy. It happens, but let's not have it happen again.

scenarios.context: After several rounds of small but repeated mistakes on a deliverable, a manager who has stayed late to help the you  pulls you aside during a team check-in.
scenarios.utterance: I you want to stay on this project, but I need someone who doesn't make mistakes.

scenarios.context: After staying late all week to fix issues caused by a faulty component, a automotive engineer speaks candidly in a one-on-one with their engineering director about a recent unilateral decision that created extra work.
scenarios.utterance: That decision really challenged us more than it should have

scenarios.context: After staying late to patch a production issue due to unrealistic deadlines, a junior engineer messages their supervisor about the decision that caused the outage.
scenarios.utterance: I think we got it fixed, but the problem may not be in the software.

scenarios.context: After you stayed late helping to prepare materials assigned to you at the last minute. Your manager skims them quickly and replies with a curt comment about timing. You respond the next morning.
scenarios.utterance: Next time, please give me a bit more notice.

scenarios.context: An adult son, juggling a demanding job, replies to his elderly father's repeated hints that he'd like a visit at the rest home. The son offers a brief, open-sounding response.
scenarios.utterance: Of course, looking forward to seeing you once I can catch a break from work.

scenarios.context: An aunt who has cancelled plans repeatedly messages her niece, who is busy with work, offering a weekend visit.
scenarios.utterance: If you're free, come over Sunday assuming my schedule clears up.

scenarios.context: An email from a senior partner to a junior associate after reading a draft brief. The partner compliments the work but says they won't be able to use it.
scenarios.utterance: Nice work on the brief, but it's not what we had in mind.

scenarios.context: An older sister is the live-in caretaker for her parents. She offers to let her younger brother move back home after he lost his job.
scenarios.utterance: You're welcome to move back in, as long as we can somehow find space.

scenarios.context: At the end of a busy Friday, the director says this to a new team member who asked for feedback.
scenarios.utterance: I'm usually very busy, but my door's open.

scenarios.context: In a project Slack channel, you missed a deadline and a teammate who has been covering for you sends a direct message after reviewing your latest comment. They've stayed late a few nights this week helping the team.
scenarios.utterance: There are serious problems with your last pitch. Let's sort it out next week.

scenarios.context: In a team Slack channel you share with a peer who stayed late to help edit your document, then posts a short line about the document
scenarios.utterance: Next time, try to finish the draft before the meeting. Good work.

scenarios.context: In the morning standup meeting, a manager responds briefly after an employee admits they're behind on deliverables and feeling overwhelmed.
scenarios.utterance: It’s fine, just focus on the high priority items and just finish the project by tomorrow morning.  We'll discuss growth after the quarter.

scenarios.context: It's 11:30 p.m. and your manager sends a Slack private message after you missed a minor deadline. Earlier that day they'd been curt in the meeting but also approved overtime on your task list.
scenarios.utterance: Don't stress and get some sleep. When you're not late your work is great.

scenarios.context: It's just past midnight. A younger sister texts her older sister upset after failing an important exam. The older sister has been visibly exhausted and stretched thin caring for the family lately and replies from bed.
scenarios.utterance: It's really important to do well in Calculus if you want to study Physics. But don't worry, I'm sure you'll get it next time.

scenarios.context: Late evening Slack thread: a junior analyst has just messaged their manager, worried about tomorrow's client presentation after missing a rehearsal earlier. The manager is replying from home after a long day.
scenarios.utterance: Don't stress about ther presentation tomorrow, if you can't handle it we can reassign it to someone else tomorrow morning.

scenarios.context: On Slack a teammate sends a private late-night message after you missed a minor deadline. Earlier that day they'd been terse in the thread and haven't offered help.
scenarios.utterance: I'm happy to help, but you've got to learn how to fix these types of problems by yourself.

scenarios.context: The manager has previously spent extra time coaching this person but on Slack the morning after an employee missed a deadline the manager sent a short message while clearly busy.
scenarios.utterance: Please don't ever miss such an important deadline again. Don't worry, I've got your back.

scenarios.context: They'd spent the morning helping their oldest sibling move boxes after that sibling repeatedly missed agreed pickup times. Near the end, while stacking the last box, the helper responds.
scenarios.utterance: Keep flaking out on us like that, and you may be an only child next time.

scenarios.context: You and your parent had a tense phone call earlier about money. They've been texting repeatedly after you moved out recently and tried setting boundaries. They text again asking if you're okay while you're at work.
scenarios.utterance: I'm fine, really. I'll get my rent money somehow.

scenarios.context: You asked your director for feedback on a draft. The director spent the afternoon in a meeting but emailed you a blunt note at 9pm.
scenarios.utterance: If you can make this draft better, please send it by tomorrow.

scenarios.context: You asked your manager about a promotion after a great performance review where they gave noncommittal feedback. They replied late in the evening and you send a short response.
scenarios.utterance: I hope I can translate your recent performance review into a bonus despite the current budget freeze.

scenarios.context: You get a late DM from a friend you haven't heard from in two months, you respond with a message worried about them. They finally reply the next day.
scenarios.utterance: Can't talk, don’t worry about it.

scenarios.context: You have been working late with a colleagues on a shared report after a missed internal deadline. Your colleague, who stayed later last night to clean up sections, messages you the next morning.
scenarios.utterance: Good work, but if you keep it up I'll never get home.

scenarios.context: You spent hours helping a close friend redo their dating profile and even stayed late to give feedback. Shortly after, you see they post something reckless and you reply quickly with a sharp line.
scenarios.utterance: Be original but don't be weird. Get it together or people might ghost you.

scenarios.context: You stayed up late to help your older sibling move into their new apartment. Your older sibling arrived late from a meeting and barely apologized. Later they send you a short message when you were awake.
scenarios.utterance: Thanks for helping out. If I knew how much work it was I would've tried sneaking out of my big meeting.

scenarios.context: You submitted a progress report late in the evening. Your manager replied quickly while still logged on.
scenarios.utterance: Is this the best we've got? I guess we'll go with it then.

scenarios.context: You texted a friend late at night saying you like them. They read it two hours later and send a short reply. You've been talking as friends for months and they sometimes flirt but lately have been quieter.
scenarios.utterance: OMG LOL

scenarios.context: You're an older friend who stayed up late to redo a younger friend's slides after they missed the practice pitch run-thru. The next morning you text them while they're at work.
scenarios.utterance: I'm sure you'll do fine given all the hard work you put into this presentation.

scenarios.context: You're on a video call with your younger sister. She just finished telling you she's anxious about an upcoming interview and has been pacing. You waited a beat before replying.
scenarios.utterance: You're doing fine. It's really important, but try not to overthink it.

scenarios.context: You've been casually dating someone who seems to be becoming more attached. They asked if you want to see each other more and you reply after thinking about your schedule.
scenarios.utterance: Absolutely! Let me see if I can fit you in between pilates and dinner.

scenarios.context: You've been checking in with a friend all week about their horrible dating experiences. They text you late one night after a terrible date. You've offered help before but have started to feel worn out by repeating yourself.
scenarios.utterance: Can't talk right now. Check my previous text advice. And don't go changing for anyone.

scenarios.context: Your an intern who stayed late defending and implementing a recent bad choice your director made. After the deployment you send an honest comment in the team channel.
scenarios.utterance: Honestly, that which doesn't kill you makes you strong.

scenarios.context: Your close friend stayed late helping you paint your kitchen last week. A few days later they call about your latest DIY project and responds bluntly.
scenarios.utterance: Glad I could help out, do you need help again?

scenarios.context: Your manager pushed an aggressive timeline that the team couldn't meet. You've repeatedly stayed late to pick up their slack and now push back in a one-line reply.
scenarios.utterance: We might burn out our team with too many late nights if we want to meet these aggressive deadlines.

scenarios.context: Your younger brother is about to give a short speech at a family event. You missed most of his rehearsals because of work and only text him from the car right before he goes on stage.
scenarios.utterance: Try to stay relaxed, this is an importat event!

scenarios.context: A father has repeatedly covered his adult daughter's share of household bills. After a month without payment, he brings it up while helping her pack laundry.
scenarios.utterance: If you'd like, I can remind you again next month about the rent. I know how you can forget sometimes.

scenarios.context: A father learns his adult child skipped another family dinner. This is the third time in a row the child has missed an important family occasion. The family has a history of the parent minimizing conflict to keep family peace.
scenarios.utterance: It's really okay that you couldn't make Mom's birthday again; we managed fine without you.

scenarios.context: A junior analyst posts a reply in a team thread after a senior analyst provided detailed critiques and requested last-minute changes to a report that was already reviewed. The team has a history of late edits from that senior analyst.
scenarios.utterance: Thanks for the notes, I'll make the edits, and hopefully next time we can avoid so many last-minute changes.

scenarios.context: A junior developer is responding to their manager after being asked to handle another round of weekend QA. The junior has been given disproportionate weekend work compared with more senior colleagues over several cycles.
scenarios.utterance: Sure, I'll take care of the extra QA this weekend, don't worry about me; I know you have more important things to do.

scenarios.context: A manager has had to remind an otherwise reliable junior analyst three times this month about late deliverables. The analyst finally hands in a report two hours after the deadline and the manager catches them in the office as they're packing up for the day.
scenarios.utterance: Great job. Take the rest of the day off, I know you've been juggling a lot.

scenarios.context: A mother notices her teenage child's socks and a few small messes have been put away after weeks of reminders about chores. The household has a history of the teen doing the minimum and the parent repeatedly nagging.
scenarios.utterance: You actually put your socks in the hamper, how civilized of you.

scenarios.context: A mother waits in the kitchen. Her adult son has a history of coming home late and leaving a mess after nights out. He walks in at 1:15 a.m.
scenarios.utterance: It's nice of you to show up.

scenarios.context: A parent has repeatedly asked their teenage child to help with household chores; the child has been skipping their turn for weeks. The parent speaks after the child says they’ll be 'too busy' again.
scenarios.utterance: It's a good thing I’m never too busy to do the things you ask me to do.

scenarios.context: A professor emails a graduate student after receiving a late revision that had already been flagged in earlier comments.
scenarios.utterance: No worries, just make sure it's truly final next time.

scenarios.context: A project coordinator had an approved day off but their manager asks them to cover a client call. The coordinator responds in person before leaving for the day.
scenarios.utterance: As you know I have my trip scheduled for today, so it will depend on flight wifi.

scenarios.context: A project director has shown a specific report with a second updated requried template in training sessions. A team member submits the report using the director's old template instead. The director sends a brief message at 5:45pm before leaving the office.
scenarios.utterance: Next time please be more careful and pay attention to details like which template you are using.

scenarios.context: A small project team on Slack. One teammate repeatedly turned in a section late; they finally posted an updated draft after the deadline and a couple of offhand reminders from others.
scenarios.utterance: No worries, that actually looks pretty good given the timeline.

scenarios.context: A team lead assigns an urgent deliverable late Friday. An associate who already planned personal commitments replies immediately in the group chat.
scenarios.utterance: No problem. I can live in the office this weekend if that helps.

scenarios.context: A team lead replies to an engineer who frequently misses morning meetings and turns in partial updates, sending a short message after another late check-in.
scenarios.utterance: No worries, whenever you're ready send the update; I know your mornings can be tough.

scenarios.context: After a family birthday cleanup, one brother sibling (the listener) repeatedly promised to take out the trash but forgot several times. The sister speaker sibling is worn out from handling most chores recently.
scenarios.utterance: No, it's fine, really. I'll just take the trash out myself; you must be exhausted.

scenarios.context: After an employee admits they overlooked an important requirement, a director responds during a quick check-in.
scenarios.utterance: Thanks for letting me know. That's really helpful. I'll rearrange my entire schedule to fit this in.

scenarios.context: After several canceled dates and last-minute changes, your partner tells you they need to leave dinner early for a work call.
scenarios.utterance: It's great that you can at least show up for your work.

scenarios.context: After several missed deadlines, a manager gives brief feedback in a one-on-one after the employee's project presentation.
scenarios.utterance: Nice presentation, for once you met the deadline.

scenarios.context: After your partner repeatedly cancels plans at the last minute, you just learned your partner now wants to go out tonight despite their earlier cancellations.
scenarios.utterance: Leave it to you to cancel a cancelation.

scenarios.context: An adult child replies to a parent's group text reminders about attending a weekly family dinner. The child lives farther away and the parent has a history of repeatedly checking in a little too often.
scenarios.utterance: Thanks for the reminder. I'll clear my schedule so you don't have to keep asking.

scenarios.context: An adult son asks his father about moving back home. The son explains his options are limited due an unexpected job loss but the father just lectures him about responsibility.
scenarios.utterance: Of course, you're the expert Dad. I should've known better, thanks for always looking out for me anyway.

scenarios.context: An older sibling drops by the younger sibling's apartment after months away. The younger sibling has a known habit of leaving clutter and never finishing chores.
scenarios.utterance: Wow, your place actually looks pretty good. I didn't expect to say that.

scenarios.context: At a family dinner, a pair of brother and sister adult siblings are taking a side dish the sister brought. The sister (the listener) has a history of undercooking or sloppily preparing food, and there has been low-level tension about it. The brother comments.
scenarios.utterance: Wow, I've never had mashed potatoes like these before. It's nice to see you trying.

scenarios.context: At a family holiday, a younger daughter is repeatedly overlooked while her father praises an older siblings going around telling the family what they've been doing. When asked if she's okay with being ignored, the younger daughter answers calmly.
scenarios.utterance: Of course, why would he ever care about me.

scenarios.context: At a family potluck, an aunt samples a niece's homemade dish that the rest of the family finds unconventional. After pausing the aunt responds.
scenarios.utterance: Thanks for bringing such a creative dish, it's always interesting to try new things.

scenarios.context: During a weekly team meeting, a colleague who often rushes their slides just finished a presentation that covered the required topics but was disorganized and didn't get to a point. A few other peers glanced at each other while the presenter packed up and one audience member quips.
scenarios.utterance: That was actually not terrible for how last-minute it was.

scenarios.context: During the weekly project review, a manager addresses a junior developer who previously turned in messy data but has improved the latest slides. Other team members are present and there's a history of missed metrics from this junior employee.
scenarios.utterance: Nice job on the slides. For once the numbers actually line up.

scenarios.context: During the weekly status meeting a manger sits through a junior analyst's presentation that was obviously hastily updated the night before. Afterward the junior analyst asks for feedback in front of the team.
scenarios.utterance: Well you must have pounded that out quickly. Well done.

scenarios.context: In a cross-functional project chat, a coworker repeatedly volunteers for high-profile tasks and later leaves execution gaps. The speaker has volunteered availability for these high-profile tasks before but feels overlooked. The team is allocating the next coding sprint tasks.
scenarios.utterance: Sure, go ahead and take the lead on this one. It's not like I haven't been available before or and its not like these tasks aren’t getting done.

scenarios.context: In a family group chat a parent responds to an adult child's message about not wanting to travel for a holiday. The parent has been disappointed by the child's choices before.
scenarios.utterance: No worries, if it's easier for you not to come then that's fine.

scenarios.context: In a friend's planning thread for weekend plans, one friend cancels last-minute for the third time this month. Another friend replies in the chat so the group sees it.
scenarios.utterance: No problem, go do what you need to do. Really, don't worry about us.

scenarios.context: In a team Slack channel for a peer software project. A teammate who has missed several deadlines just posted a late-but-working patch fix and a short summary of what they changed.
scenarios.utterance: Nice, it actually works.

scenarios.context: In a team code-review thread at work, one peer submits a code fix in a pull request that had been delayed several times. Another colleague posts a short comment after finally seeing it merged into the main codebase.
scenarios.utterance: Thanks for getting this in eventually.

scenarios.context: In the project's Slack channel, the engineering manager announced a new, earlier deadline late in the day. The junior developer, who has limited time and less power to push back, replies in the channel where the manager and other leads can see it.
scenarios.utterance: No problem. I'll get it done by Friday. Thanks for the late notice!

scenarios.context: On Slack the manager replies to an intern who just uploaded a file later than requested and labelled it poorly.
scenarios.utterance: Thanks for sending this over. Better on time than done right.

scenarios.context: On Slack, a department manager replies after a junior analyst finally uploads a report that had been overdue despite multiple reminders.
scenarios.utterance: Thanks for finally sending the report. I hope the extra time means it's an extra good report.

scenarios.context: On a company's editorial Slack channel, a senior editor responds to an intern's draft for a public post.
scenarios.utterance: That's a cute take. Maybe try rewording it to sound more professional before you post.

scenarios.context: Two adult siblings coordinate driving their elderly parent to a mid-morning medical appointment. The younger sibling texts that they'll be a bit late because of work, and the older sibling, who has done most of the rides lately, replies immediately.
scenarios.utterance: Oh, that's fine take as long as you need. I’ve got all the time in the world like always.

scenarios.context: Two colleagues in the same product team just finished a client demo. The presentation creator has repeatedly covered for the presenter when they were unprepared in past meetings, now the creator is standing near the coffee machine as others congratulate the presenter.
scenarios.utterance: Wow, you actually handled that presentation really well. How did you pull that off?

scenarios.context: You and a close friend finally meet up after they've canceled plans several times over the past month. Your friend arrive late, apologetic but smiling while you stand waiting.
scenarios.utterance: Oh, you finally made it. I’m just glad I’m important enough for you to show up eventually.

scenarios.context: You and a friend are deciding plans for a group date night. The friend tends to make all the decisions and dismisses your ideas instead opting for a risky attempt to get late tickets to a concert. When they announce their plan, you reluctantly concede.
scenarios.utterance: Okay, do it your way. There’s always a chance it works out.

scenarios.context: You and a friend had plans to go out. Your friend (who usually calls the shots socially) cancels last minute yet again. You respond when they apologize.
scenarios.utterance: It's fine, don't worry about it. I'm happy to stay in again.

scenarios.context: You and a friend have been organizing a small get-together. Your friend promised to bring pastries but forgot and messaged last-minute. You've been handling most logistics lately and are quietly frustrated but don't want a full argument before guests arrive.
scenarios.utterance: Don't worry about the pastries, I can just take care of it with everything else.

scenarios.context: You and a younger friend meet after your friend got a very different, edgy haircut you had no idea about. You previously joked about how they always change styles without thinking. You're sitting in a cafe and your friend asks what you think of their new edgy haircut.
scenarios.utterance: It actually kind of suits you.

scenarios.context: You and your romantic partner share an apartment. They've been repeatedly leaving dishes in the sink and saying they'll do them later. You usually end up cleaning them. After another night of you washing alone, you hand your partner a towel while they're scrolling on the couch.
scenarios.utterance: Don't worry, you’ve got this, the instructions are in the sink.

scenarios.context: You and your sibling usually trade cooking and chores. Lately they cancel plans and expect you to cover evenings. Tonight they say they need to head out with friends right before dinner.
scenarios.utterance: Oh, it's fine go ahead and go; I can make dinner again, don't worry about me.

scenarios.context: You are in a group chat with friends planning a weekend trip where others are choosing dates and activities without asking. One member who has been quieter lately speaks up
scenarios.utterance: Sure, go ahead and book whatever works for you. I don't want to be a burden.

scenarios.context: You asked your sibling (who usually organizes family gatherings) whether you'll be included in a small holiday dinner. Your sibling replied that the guest list is limited. You're older but currently living with them, and you don't want to start a fight before other relatives visit.
scenarios.utterance: No, it's fine, you should invite whoever makes you happiest. I wouldn't want to cause any trouble.

scenarios.context: You have often been the one to rearrange plans with your old friend group when a newer member joins and tends to cancel last minute. After the new friend cancels again citing 'unexpected work stuff,' you message them while organizing the week.
scenarios.utterance: No problem at all. Text me when you're free next and I'll find a time that works for you.

scenarios.context: You have repeatedly warned your oldest friend about their new girlfriend. You see a scandalous photo of the two together on Instagram and send a short text.
scenarios.utterance: I really hope you’re keeping in mind how difficult it is to delete things from the internet.

scenarios.context: You lent a favorite jacket to a close friend for a concert; they returned it with a faint wine stain and the sleeve a bit stretched. This isn't the first time they've been careless with your things, and you haven't directly complained before.
scenarios.utterance: Thanks for bringing my jacket back, its almost like new.

scenarios.context: You lent a friend some money a few weeks ago. They've been promising to repay but keep postponing and giving excuses. You bumped into them at a coffee shop after another excuse.
scenarios.utterance: It seems like you aren’t having trouble getting money together for things like coffee.

scenarios.context: You notice your best friend's spouse missed their planned anniversary dinner, after being stood up many times before. You send a message to your friend’s spouse.
scenarios.utterance: I hope whatever reason you had to miss your anniversary dinner was worth it.

scenarios.context: You planned a small anniversary dinner with your partner, but they forgot and spent the evening with friends. Your partner apologized the next day. You are both tired and still living in the same place, so direct confrontation would escalate things.
scenarios.utterance: It's totally fine. Don't worry about it, I'm glad you had a nice night.

scenarios.context: You were passed over for a promotion again in favor of an external hire. You tell your supervisor this right after the announcement.
scenarios.utterance: No worries at all. Maybe it's good to have an outsider who isn’t part of this company.

scenarios.context: You're driving a younger friend to a group dinner after their recent messy breakup. Your younger friend is trying a new, more polished look tonight. You've seen them in more casual outfits for months and have a history of teasing them.
scenarios.utterance: You look really great tonight. I'm honestly impressed.

scenarios.context: You've been dating casually; the other person has canceled plans three times in the past month for similar reasons. They cancel again tonight, saying they have to work late. You're disappointed but trying not to seem clingy.
scenarios.utterance: Alright, whatever works for you, you let me know if you ever want to meet up.

scenarios.context: You've been texting a friend who often cancels last-minute. Tonight they finally show up for a movie they promised weeks ago but were late and distracted. You're quieter than usual.
scenarios.utterance: Nice of you to make time. I'm glad you could fit me in.

scenarios.context: You've made plans with someone you're dating who has a pattern of canceling last-minute. Tonight they text that they won't make it again with a vague excuse.
scenarios.utterance: That's okay. You go have fun, and maybe we wait to make plans until you can keep them.

scenarios.context: Your manager assigns you an extra task on Friday afternoon and explicitly suggests you handle it over the weekend because they don't have time. You reply in the thread to confirm.
scenarios.utterance: Don't worry about asking me to do more work on the weekend, it’s fine.

scenarios.context: A college student comes home after their parent cleaned out their childhood bedroom and discarded several things the student cared about. The student sees the mostly empty room and says to their parent.
scenarios.utterance: Well now I know what you really ment when you asked me to 'clean my room' all those years growing up here.

scenarios.context: A developer in code review notices that a new programmer merged an untested change that broke the build late on a Friday. The developer posts to the team chat.
scenarios.utterance: Nice job merging your updatesÉ exactly what we needed on a Friday afternoon.

scenarios.context: A double date you helped coordinate for you and your friend went badly: both couples argued, the booked activity was cancelled, and everyone left early. After the disasterous date, your friend turns to you.
scenarios.utterance: So what are you thinking about our next double date, Tuesday?

scenarios.context: A father comes home to find the teenager's spilled food, a stack of dirty plates, and clothes all over the living room. Guests are due in an hour, so the father speaks.
scenarios.utterance: Thanks for helping clean-up before our guests arrive, but I think you missed a few spots.

scenarios.context: A group of friends drove into town to see a small local band, but five minutes before the set the venue texts that the band canceled. You're all standing in the street, late and annoyed.
scenarios.utterance: We can cram into my care. I think I can get reception on a few AM radio station.

scenarios.context: A junior developer just spent the morning presenting a design proposal their manager quickly dismissed in front of everyone. The manager then gave the junior developer a single vague sentence of feedback and moved on.
scenarios.utterance: I guess I left him nearly speechless which is either really good or really bad?

scenarios.context: A junior resident had pointed out several risks in an medical operation, but their senior attending physician overrides any concerns raised. The operation results in major medical complications and a large lawsuit. When the senior attending physician tries the shift blame to the junior resident, the junior resident responds.
scenarios.utterance: It's unfortunate no one raised any objections to the risks involved in this operation.

scenarios.context: A movie critic posts a scathing review of the debut novel by your friend who is a feature new author in a New Yorker book review.  Your new author friend turns to you.
scenarios.utterance: They say those can do, those who can't critique. Looks like I have a promising second career.

scenarios.context: A scheduled controlled forest burn escaped and accidently damanged thousands of acres. The governor gathers all the leaders involved to address them.
scenarios.utterance: I think you left out one of the words in the phrase "controlled forrest burn".

scenarios.context: A teen daughter asks her mother for a birthday cake which comes out burnt on the edges and collapsed. The mother proudly brings the messy cake into the kitchen where family is gathered.
scenarios.utterance: Perfect, no one will confust this is a store-brought birthday cake. Look at all that love in it.

scenarios.context: A utility company manager asks the company's webmaster to post an electricity outage message on the company's website.
scenarios.utterance: Well at least our CEO got his performance bonus this quarter.

scenarios.context: A waiter just knocked a tall cafŽ latte all over their your brand-new laptop while trying to help clean the adjacent tabletop. You immediately grab your laptop, turn it upside down so coffee can drip off your keyboard looking clearly upset.
scenarios.utterance: I hope you're not expecting another tip for that.

scenarios.context: After a chaotic family board-game night with accusation of cheating  and one sibling (Amy) storming out, you're left collecting pieces and trying to calm down the other family members.
scenarios.utterance: Well, cheaters never win so I know Amy wasn't accusing me.

scenarios.context: After a client presentation went off the rails because the manager forgot the slide deck, an his intern nephwe turns to the manager in the meeting room.
scenarios.utterance: Wow, so that's what they pay you the big bucks for.

scenarios.context: After a difficult negotiation call where the supplier was foced to slash their wholesale price in the face of pressure for a large retailer, the supplier's lawyer turns to the supplier's lead negotiator and speaks.
scenarios.utterance: You really drove a hard bargain. That's going to leave a mark for days.

scenarios.context: After a meeting in which the CEO harshly criticized the new fashion rollout in front of the team, a designer stops the CEO in the hallway.
scenarios.utterance: I guess the finance guys driving this fashion line are better at numbers than fashion.

scenarios.context: After the programmer accidentally pushed a code update that reverted most of the day's progress, another teammate sighs and addresses the small group of peers who worked on it together.
scenarios.utterance: Well, that went... great.

scenarios.context: An older sibling discovers their younger sister forgot to book their shared flight home, which means the both sibling missed a major family reunion.
scenarios.utterance: Nice work on missing the family reunion. I'm sure they were getting tired of us anyway.

scenarios.context: At a cozy weeknight dinner at home, your older, more socially assured friend (who often teases you) watches you set off the smoke alarm while trying a new recipe. They're standing at the doorway with a mix of amusement and exasperation.
scenarios.utterance: I like your musical selection in paring the piercing alarm sirens with charcol brisket

scenarios.context: At a family dinner, the younger sibling cooked a nostalgic casserole from their childhood but it was clearly overcooked and salty. The older sibling sits down, tastes it while the younger sibling watches nervously,dicussing found memories of their parents. The older sibling comments after swalloing their first bite.
scenarios.utterance: Wow, it didn't think anyone could do it, but you've outdone mom's own casserole.

scenarios.context: At a family dinner, the younger sibling volunteered to cook for everyone for the first time but accidentally burned the main dish. The parents are trying not to make the younger sibling feel worse. After one bite, the older sibling quips:
scenarios.utterance: Wow, this tastes just like a five-star restaurant.

scenarios.context: At a small house party the you accidentally mentioned a private story about you new partner in front of the your ex, causing visible embarrassment. Your new partner feels betrayed, responds with a short remark.
scenarios.utterance: Glad to know you stay on intimate terms with both your current and future ex's

scenarios.context: At a small house party, you introduce your recent ex to you new partner. The introduction made several people visibly uncomfortable and led to awkward, clipped conversation. Later, another friend tries to comment while the group processes the moment.
scenarios.utterance: That definitely wasn't a total disaster.

scenarios.context: At the all-hands launch party with media and investors, the startup development manager revealed to a stranger the software is unstable due to several critical bugs. It turns out the stranger is a tech reporter who only reveals their identity later, and then leaves with this comment.
scenarios.utterance: Don't worry, your secret is safe with me and my YouTube subscribers - we'll keep it between the 700k of us.

scenarios.context: At the family Thanksgiving dinner, the younger sister was assigned to roast the turkey and accidentally left it in the oven until it burned. Everyone is seated around the nicely plated charred turkey when grandmother speaks up.
scenarios.utterance: Well I don't know about everyone else, but I actually prefer my meat well-done.

scenarios.context: Both political candidates' opening debate statements contained several serious factual errors and awkward pauses. After these openings, one of the campaign managers enthusiastically remarked to a skeptical member of the TV crew.
scenarios.utterance: Wow, that presentation was absolutely flawless.

scenarios.context: Bringing a new transformer online resulted with a major electrical outage affecting several neighborhoods in a major city. The utility company CEO who managed the project sits next to the mayor facing an upcoming election. The two exchange tense before a press conference.
scenarios.utterance: Thanks for helping get out the vote for my opponent next week

scenarios.context: During a live product demo to executives, the prototype froze after the director insisted on showing the new feature right away. The junior developer who had to restart the demo is now speaking to that director in the team chat after the meeting.
scenarios.utterance: Hopefully the audience thought the pause was a tomato timer feature, not a bug.

scenarios.context: During a post operation discussion, the assisting surgeon realizes the main surgeon left a sponge in the patient's abdomin.
scenarios.utterance: I hope his insurance pays for that extra sponge or it's coming out of your paycheck

scenarios.context: During the all-hands meeting after this morning's  product launch failed spectacularly, the director turns to the project lead.
scenarios.utterance: Fantastic, you're going to be remembered for this launch.

scenarios.context: During the early morning econ class, a student fell asleep in the first row. Upon seeing this, the professor addresses the rest of the class.
scenarios.utterance: Note the surest way to an A grade: a willing spirit with a weak body.

scenarios.context: During the official state dinner, the vegetables were overcooked and the fish undercooked. The ambassador looks embarrassed. His counterpart across the table, comments while everyone stares at the food.
scenarios.utterance: In my country our food is prepared the opposite: raw vegetables and cooked fish.

scenarios.context: During the weekly check-in with his parole officer, the ex-con was consistently late by 15-30mins every time.
scenarios.utterance: When you make me wait it feels like I'm doing hard time.

scenarios.context: During their lunch break, the junior mechanic comes across lug nuts he accidentally forgot to put back on a customer's car. He asks a senior mechanic what he should do about it.
scenarios.utterance: No worries, I'm sure no one will notice.

scenarios.context: In a kitchen renovation contract you signed, the contractor had agreed on a deadline. The contractor missed the deadeline and apologized saying they'll finish by next month.
scenarios.utterance: No rush, it's much easier to prepare meals in the laundry room utility sink - so much more room.

scenarios.context: In a project meeting a tech running the demo couldn't get the it working, and the presenter found slides were missing. So they both hurriedly skipped explanations while others stared.
scenarios.utterance: Well, that went perfectly.

scenarios.context: In the team's Slack channel, a colleague posts a PDF of the monthly report five hours late. It has several factual errors and broken charts. The team is waiting on this for a meeting. A peer replies in the thread.
scenarios.utterance: Oh wow, that report was... a triple double.

scenarios.context: Morgan promised to feed Carl's fish while Carl was on extended vacation. Morgan accidently fed the fish the wrong pet food which proved toxic. Staring at all his dead tropical fish floating upside down at the top of their fishtank, Carl notes:
scenarios.utterance: Well at least you remembered to feed them.

scenarios.context: On a blind date with Alice, her date repeatedly tripped over their words, accidentally knocked over Alice's wine, and dominated the conversation. Alice meets her friend who set up the date later. When her friend asks how her blind date went, Alice responds.
scenarios.utterance: I think they thought it was more of a blind, deaf and dumb date.

scenarios.context: On a long group hiking trip into primative park forests, everyone thought someone else was packing toilet paper for the group.  The hiking leader addresses everyone around a campfire about the confusion.
scenarios.utterance: I guess we'll all really find out what the meaning of "roughing it" means this week

scenarios.context: Right before the big media demo, a junior developer accidentally pushed an update that crashed the website. A senior manager pulls the junior developer aside.
scenarios.utterance: Don't worry, I'm sure the media is here to see me and not the new product.

scenarios.context: Siblings were coordinating the surprise birthday for their mother. Sam was supposed to pick up the cake but forgot, and the group is standing awkwardly around with everything but the centerpiece cake. Sam's oldest sibling note.
scenarios.utterance: Don't sweat it Sam, at least we remembered the important stuff: confetting, streamers, and plates.

scenarios.context: The new attorney spent hours preparing a his case presentation for a senior  partner in their law firm. Although the presention itself was sound, the new attorney stumbled over thier words, frequently lost track of their arguments, and appeared nervious throughout. After the conclusion of the presentation, the senior partner gave this feedback.
scenarios.utterance: I'm sure the solid content will make up for the poor delivery.

scenarios.context: When website traffic actually fell after the multi-million dollar ad campaign,  the CEO sent a curt, disappointed email to their social media manager.
scenarios.utterance: You were supposed to drive internet traffic TO our website, not the other way around.

scenarios.context: You and a close friend had a reservation for a small birthday dinner. They showed up almost two hours late, missed the group photo, and walked in as the cake was being cut. A few people had already left. As they sit down, you say something to them.
scenarios.utterance: And I thought our jump scare was good, but you really surprised the birthday boy with your dramatic delayed entrance.

scenarios.context: You and a friend are getting ready for a double date. As the other person's date arrives, your friend knocks over a glass of red wine all over their partner's white shirt.
scenarios.utterance: Great! Now I'm going to have to spill a glass of wine too so our dates match.

scenarios.context: You and a more socially dominant friend went on a double date. Your date monopolized the conversation and made a few awkward comments that left you embarrassed in front of the other couple.
scenarios.utterance: Well at least I couldn't put my foot in my mouth since I couldn't get a word in edgewise.

scenarios.context: You and your partner (they're older and usually take the lead in plans) had tickets for a show tonight. Your partner forgot the tickets at home and you missed the start.
scenarios.utterance: Well the really important people show up fashionably late anyway

scenarios.context: You and your roommate had agreed to share groceries. Tonight you open the fridge to find the last container of food gone and a note from your roommate apologizing that they already ate it.
scenarios.utterance: So this is why communism failed, your needs obviously out paced my abilities.

scenarios.context: You and your younger sibling share hotel room on a famliy vacation. Your younger sibling races to the room, unpacks their clothes, and sprawls on the better bed before you get to the room. You're standing in the doorway looking at the situation.
scenarios.utterance: Wow, how thoughtful.

scenarios.context: You asked an older friend (who usually gives advice and feels responsible for you) for dating tips. After following their suggestion you had an awkward, worse date. They text you afterward while you both process it.
scenarios.utterance: You do know I was joking don't you.

scenarios.context: You come home to find the living room covered in confetti, spilled snacks, and a cracked family vase after your teenage child threw an unsupervised party despite repeated warnings. Your teenager speaks to you.
scenarios.utterance: You know, sometimes looks can be deciving.

scenarios.context: You lent your car to your younger sister. The younger sister returned it with a large, obvious dent. You are in the driveway, looking at the damage.
scenarios.utterance: I like the new aerodynmic curves you added to the passenger doors.

scenarios.context: You met your ex and your ex's partner's at a small gathering of a common friend with your new partner. Later, talking to your new partner, you make this remark the heated argument you saw between your ex and their new partner.
scenarios.utterance: Well, I guess I it wasn't just me after all.

scenarios.context: You planned a surprise anniversary dinner for your significant other. When you unexpectedly arrive home early from work with balloons, champagne, and a cake you find your significant other romantically entwined with the apartment handyman. Your significant other turns to you and explains.
scenarios.utterance: I guess your not the only one with a surprise?

scenarios.context: You planned an expensive dinner at a fancy restaurant with your new partner. They arrived two hours late without apologizing and then said they'd 'changed plans' so the reservation was lost.
scenarios.utterance: Don't worry, I've made backup reservations at McDonalds.

scenarios.context: You tried to fix the bathroom sink and ended up flooding the floor. Your spouse is watching the mess and notes that guests arrive in less than an hour.
scenarios.utterance: How thoughtful. Instead of making our guests walk to the bathroom, I guess we'll just bring the bathroom to them.

scenarios.context: You're a forum user whose post was removed and who received a firm, public warning from a moderator. You message the moderator directly afterward.
scenarios.utterance: That was some moderation skill on displayÉ

scenarios.context: Your blind date was an hour late and spent most of the night scrolling through their phone. You call your sister who set you up the next day.
scenarios.utterance: I think we were most compatible on the apathy level.

scenarios.context: Your on a first date at a diner when you trip and knocked your date's desert onto the floor. While you're kneeling on the floor to clean up, you date say
scenarios.utterance: Don't bother, I prefer my apple pie a la linolium.

scenarios.context: A close friend is talking to you about a flaky romantic partner they're clearly infatuated with recently. Your friend brings up concerns after noticing a pattern of letdowns.
scenarios.utterance: That's distressing. I just want you to be with someone who treats you more consistently.

scenarios.context: A coworker is attempting to replicate for innovative work that you've spent years developing. When you request a department meeting to discuss, they are evasive and delay.
scenarios.utterance: It seems your recent efforts are replicating existing work. Let's call a department meeting to improve coordination and collaboration.

scenarios.context: A customer support specialist texts you (their manager) declining to pick up an extra overnight shift you requested for the coming busy shopping weekend.
scenarios.utterance: We really need your help for the overnight shift this weekend, it's the busiest time of our year. Let me make it up to you later somehow.

scenarios.context: A director replies to a senior associate who volunteered to take on an extra task during an especially busy quarter.
scenarios.utterance: I appreciate you offering to help, but you've already got so much on your plate. I'll take care of this one myself, but reach out if I need help.

scenarios.context: A faculty advisor replies to a student's email asking to join an ongoing research project.
scenarios.utterance: I appreciate your interest. I don't think this particular project is the best match right now, but I encourage you to look into other opportunities in the lab.

scenarios.context: A father is discussing job-search progress with his adult child who has applied for several positions (probably well beyond their qualifications) without success.
scenarios.utterance: I'm really proud of how proactive you've been in applying. That said, I don't think these particular role is the best fit for you right now, but I know you'll find something that suits you better.

scenarios.context: A father is responding to his adult child who just told him they didn't get a promotion they interviewed for; they're speaking over the phone.
scenarios.utterance: This one probably wasn't the right fit, but I'm proud of how you put yourself out there.

scenarios.context: A friend (using the same dating-app you've successfully used) asks you to review a short bio and you give a quick line-by-line reaction. Your friend's short bio is terrible partner repellant.
scenarios.utterance: I like your photos, you come across really confident. Maybe drop the self-deprecating 'hopeless at dating' line and consider a complete textaul makeover.

scenarios.context: A friend asks you to help them move into their apartment this weekend. You feel overwhelmed and need to set a boundary but don't want to escalate.
scenarios.utterance: I really wish I could help you move this weekend, but I already have plans with family. I hope that's okay.

scenarios.context: A friend who usually makes last-minute plans is telling you they can't keep accommodating you after repeated cancellations.
scenarios.utterance: I apologize my schedule is so rigid and requires a little bit more planning.

scenarios.context: A grandparent responds to their grown child's last-minute request to babysit on a weekend they had already planned for themselves.
scenarios.utterance: I'd love to babysit, but I can't this weekend. Please tell me if there's another way I can help.

scenarios.context: A man posts in a group chat asking if anyone can cover a weekend shift, and another friend responds. This is his third request this month.
scenarios.utterance: I wish I could help with your shift this weekend, but I have family obligations. Good luck.

scenarios.context: A mentor who has more dating experience is talking over coffee with a younger man who's excited about a new dating prospect and wants honest input. You think the new dating prospect sound like trouble, but the y oung man appears enthralled.
scenarios.utterance: It's great your excited about your new dating prospect, and they seem really sweet. However, maybe you should spend a little more time to get to know each other better before getting in so deep.

scenarios.context: A meticulous senior community moderator responds to a sloppy junior volunteer who offered to cover extra moderation shifts over email.
scenarios.utterance: I really appreciate you offering to cover, but I think we'll handle it internally this time. Thanks for checking!

scenarios.context: A parent is responding to an adult child's request to move back into the family home for a few months.
scenarios.utterance: I wish I could help more, but I don't think moving back in is a good idea right now; let's talk about other ways I can support you.

scenarios.context: A product analyst writes to their product lead in an online document review thread about a roadmap draft they were asked to support but seems fundamentallyl flawed.
scenarios.utterance: I really appreciate how you brought the team together on this. The roadmap looks promising, but there are a few spots where additional customer data would strengthen the case - could we discuss revisions off-line?

scenarios.context: A professor emails a grad student about their seminar paper draft the student feels is perfect one week before a conference submission deadline.
scenarios.utterance: This draft shows a lot of promise and your sources are well chosen; there are some structural issues that need tightening, but with a few focused revisions this could be an excellent conference paper.

scenarios.context: A professor emails a student about the student's recently submitted class assignment that fell far short of expectations.
scenarios.utterance: Your introduction is strong and I appreciate the effort, but the methodology section onward still needs substantial work. With revisions I think this could be a solid paper.

scenarios.context: A professor emails a student after a draft presentation that covered outcomes but skipped critical citations the committee expects.
scenarios.utterance: You handled the questions well and raised interesting points. I'm confident you'll polish it before submission.

scenarios.context: A professor replies by email to a graduate student who asked for a glowing recommendation (they honestly do not deserve) for a competitive fellowship.
scenarios.utterance: I don't think I'm the best person to write the kind of recommendation you're hoping for; I'd rather step aside so you can find someone who can better speak to your fit.

scenarios.context: A professor returns a draft to a student with general comments about structure and argumentation.
scenarios.utterance: You've made some thoughtful points and, while there are several structural issues that need addressing, I'm confident you can revise this into something excellent.

scenarios.context: A short group message from a junior analyst to their department head after a weekly meeting where the head's notes and follow-ups were disorganized.
scenarios.utterance: I really appreciate how you push us to think bigger. That said, some of the follow-up notes were hard to follow. Maybe we could standardize the format? You're always so supportive of the team.

scenarios.context: A teammate asks you last-minute to take on part of their workload for the upcoming project. You respond in your team chat.
scenarios.utterance: I love that you asked, but I'm going to pass on taking this. I don't have the bandwidth this quarter, but thanks for thinking of me.

scenarios.context: A teenager asks their parent for a later curfew after a hard week of exams. They butter up their parents with praise of the parent's support through the exams.
scenarios.utterance: You always make sure everything's taken care of and I really appreciate how much you do for me; would it be okay if I came home a little later on Friday? I promise I'll be responsible.

scenarios.context: A tired parent speaks to their adult child who often starts chores but leaves things unfinished around the house.
scenarios.utterance: I really appreciate how much you try to help, I know you mean well.

scenarios.context: A wealthy friend orders the most expensive items on the menu, but when it comes to splitting the bill they only want to split it evenly among friends. You and your friends are cash-strapped and ordered more inexpensive, simplier meals.
scenarios.utterance: Wow, that lot of money than I budgeted for tonight. I don't think I ordered that much, let's take a closer look at the itemized bill.

scenarios.context: A you lend your city pie de tierre (apartment) occasionally to a younger friend but decide they can no longer host weekend guests there every week.
scenarios.utterance: I like helping your dating life out, but I can't have you crashing in my apartment every weekend.

scenarios.context: A you privately replies in a group chat after someone asks to borrow money for rent.
scenarios.utterance: I really wish I could help right now, but I can't contribute at the moment. I hope you understand.

scenarios.context: After a colleague's client-facing presentation which contained several critical factual errors, you send a follow-up message in the team chat.
scenarios.utterance: Nice work on the presentation. It looked polished overall, but there were a few gaps in the data that we'd need to tighten up for the client, but great job pulling it together.

scenarios.context: After a few months of dating, you texts your partner to explain to them how you're feeling about the relationship and to propose some distance.
scenarios.utterance: You're such a thoughtful person and I really value our time together, but I think I need to spend more time with me right now.

scenarios.context: After a first date, you text them to wrap things up. You want to be kind but end the possibility of another date.
scenarios.utterance: You're so kind and I had a nice time tonight. I just don't think we're quite right for each other.
