scenarios.context: After a third date, your close friend asks your opinion about a eccentric person they're seeing; you give a measured response.
scenarios.utterance: Your new partner is really vivacious. You know I'm here for you.

scenarios.context: After a virtual presentation, a you post feedback in the team Slack channel praising the presenter and suggesting a small change.
scenarios.utterance: Great job on the presentation! You covered the main points clearly. One small suggestion: tighten the intro by about a minute so we don't run over. Otherwise, really strong session!

scenarios.context: An adult child is asked by a parent to help with re-roofing their vacation house the coming weekend, but the adult child already has limited time and lots of responsibilities with their own family home.
scenarios.utterance: I sure wish I could help out, but this weekend is crazy. I hope it goes smoothly. Maybe I can lend a hand another time.

scenarios.context: An adult child of yours has been living in your house for several years after graduating college. You raises the topic of future plans over coffee.
scenarios.utterance: You've made this place your own, and I know you're comfortable, but maybe when you're ready you should start looking for your own place.

scenarios.context: An adult child who works full time is talking to their elderly parent who has been asking for weekly in-home help. The adult is exhausted but wants to remain polite.
scenarios.utterance: I really wish I could help more, but I can't commit to coming over every weekend. Would it be okay if we scheduled a visit and see how it goes?

scenarios.context: An employee asked their manager for extra vacation days during a busy quarter. The manager is responding by email.
scenarios.utterance: I really value your initiative and the work you do, but additional vacation days this quarter would be difficult.

scenarios.context: An old friend who has previously lent you money several times politely tells you they can't this time.
scenarios.utterance: I have a lot bills piling up right now, but I hope you can find another solution soon.

scenarios.context: An older sibling who usually helps their elderly parents texts a younger sibling who also lives nearby but rarely helps out.
scenarios.utterance: You always brighten our parents days when you show up, and they love that about you. If you could just schedule more time to help them out that would be great.

scenarios.context: An overworked junior account manager replies to a director's email asking whether they can absorb several extra clients next month.
scenarios.utterance: Thank you for trusting me with this, I'm grateful for the opportunity. Unfortunately, I won't be able to take on additional accounts this month, but am happy to discuss alternatives.

scenarios.context: At a family potluck your cousin brought a homemade potato salad that tastes like dry wall spackle. You cousin comes up and asks you how you find their potato salad.
scenarios.utterance: It looks so colorful, it must have taken you a lot of time to prepare.

scenarios.context: At family dinner, one sibling asks for you feedback on a bestman speech they're planning to read at their friend's wedding. It's horribly inappropriate.
scenarios.utterance: The opening line is lovely, but you might want to soften the humor it in light of your audience.

scenarios.context: During a peer code review you want to point out structural problems but also acknowledge the parts that are done well.
scenarios.utterance: This is a solid foundation and you handled the edge cases well; there are some structural issues that will make maintenance hard if we ship it as-is, so let's refactor those parts before merge—otherwise great work.

scenarios.context: For your parents 50th anniversary, your dominating older brother want to raise money for a trip to visit them in Seattle. Your other siblings and you live elsewhere and would rather fly them to their childhood home in Hawaii.
scenarios.utterance: Yes, let's raise money from the siblings to send them on a great 50th anniversary trip. Why don't we all get together to brainstorm ideas?

scenarios.context: In a project channel a manager evaluates a colleague's draft and offers a wrapped critique that praises effort before suggesting reassignment.
scenarios.utterance: You bring strong ideas and I appreciate the effort, but this draft slightly misses the target. Maybe this topic would be a better fit for someone else, and I'm happy to help reassign or rework it.

scenarios.context: My older sister asked to borrow money for a weekend trip. You're younger, on a tight budget, and want to refuse without escalating into an argument.
scenarios.utterance: You're always so generous and I hate to say no, but I can't lend you money right now. I'm trying to stick to a budget.

scenarios.context: On Slack you reply to a senior lead who just posted a new, unrealistic deadline for a project you're responsible for.
scenarios.utterance: Thanks for the update. I'll do my best to align with that by next sprint, but we might want to discuss alternative backup plans.

scenarios.context: Slack thread between a developer manager and the project manager about a feature deadline. The developer manager has reviewed the project manager's proposed unrealistic timeline.
scenarios.utterance: Thanks for laying this out. It seems a bit ambitious for the scope we agreed on. I can try to hit it, but I worry quality will suffer unless we adjust the timeline.

scenarios.context: Two siblings discuss a violin solo rehearsal the brother did for a family event. The sister has a history of blunt feedback but often softens criticism to avoid hurting feelings.
scenarios.utterance: You were really confident during most of it, and I loved your opening and finish. Keep that up.

scenarios.context: You and a close friend co-hosted a small dinner party for a couple from work. They arrived 40 minutes late and didn't warn anyone. Later you send a short message about timing for future plans.
scenarios.utterance: We can push our dinner plans later into the evening if that's a better fit for your schedule. Perhaps that would help the rest of us a lot.

scenarios.context: You and a fellow researcher are discussing a controversial topic with a third collaborator related to a paper all of you are working on. Your fellow researcher cites a foundational paper that have very recently been contradicted by more through peer-reviewed research.  You don't want to embarrass your fellow researcher, but it's important that all three of you work from the most recent, correct studies.
scenarios.utterance: Yes, that's a highly cited paper, but I think I might've heard some important new findings came out about that recently. Maybe I could look into it tomorrow.

scenarios.context: You and a peer were collaborating on a joint report. They just uploaded their draft later than expected which contains nothing useful that isn't already in your current report version. The team's deadline is tomorrow.
scenarios.utterance: Thanks for getting this in. It's a bit behind where we're already at. Given tomorrows deadline, perhaps we can think about coordinating better on the next project?

scenarios.context: You and a teammate are collaborating on an major analyst report for work. They created a unusable first draft with AI to claim first authorship, but it is so bad you will have to redo it from scratch.
scenarios.utterance: Thanks, this is a solid start, but it's a bit misaligned with the project? Let me take a stab at it with fresh eyes.

scenarios.context: You are already overloaded and regularly staying late at work. A colleague requests you to take on additional client account responsibilities.
scenarios.utterance: You're doing great work with your clients. Unfortunately, I can't take on that extra work right now, but let me know if I can help you brainstorm a plan.

scenarios.context: You are giving dating feedback to a long-time friend after they complained their texts are being ignored by someone they like.
scenarios.utterance: You're great at starting conversations, but maybe slow the messages a bit so you don't overwhelm them. You don't want your intensity to scare people off.

scenarios.context: You ask a colleague to cover part of your workload for the next two weeks so you can join an exciting new project part-time. The colleague replies by email.
scenarios.utterance: I wish I could help, but I can't take this on right now. I'm joining another exciting new project part-time.

scenarios.context: You often host group outings gives one of your quieter friends feedback after a date where your friend dominated conversation.
scenarios.utterance: You can really open up when you want to, but maybe hold back a bit on the storytelling. People will appreciate you even more.

scenarios.context: You share a small apartment with a friend. Your roommate has been late doing dishes and leaving food on the counter for several days. After a long shift you come home to another mess and speak up.
scenarios.utterance: Hey, I know you've been swamped lately. Thanks for picking up last week, but  could you try to stay on top of the dishes this week?

scenarios.context: You talk with a cousins you are close to about money. Your cousin asks to borrow a sum, and you reply after checking your own budget and recent obligations.
scenarios.utterance: I really wish I could help you out. I hope you understand.

scenarios.context: Your younger sibling just finished a practice run of a presentation for a family gathering. You want to be encouraging but also point out issues they should fix before the real talk.
scenarios.utterance: You kept your composure well and there were definitely strong parts. There are a few places I'd tighten up. I think people will respond to the main message.
